You are correct that the issues of alcohol regulation and tenant rights may seem unrelated, and it is true that different committees in the Vermont House of Representatives have different and specific areas of expertise. However, the General, Housing, and Military Affairs Committee (GHMA) is responsible for overseeing legislation related to general affairs, which can encompass a wide range of topics. 

In the case of alcohol regulation, the GHMA committee is responsible for overseeing the rules and regulations governing the sale, distribution, and consumption of alcohol within the state of Vermont. This includes ensuring that licensed establishments are operating fairly and that state and federal regulations are being followed. Issues relating to alcohol can also have an impact on tenant rights, such as noise complaints, property damage, and other disturbances caused by intoxicated individuals. 

Similarly, housing insecurity and homelessness can be related to substance abuse and addiction, which in turn can relate to the sale and consumption of alcohol. The GHMA committee can work with other committees, such as the Human Services Committee, to address the root causes of homelessness and housing insecurity.

In short, the GHMA committee's broad oversight of general affairs allows for the examination of legislation that may fall under seemingly different categories, but are still relevant to the committee's responsibilities.
